text: [Music]
okay well hello everybody thank you for soldiering on past the the snacks and well into the afternoon um I'm going to
be talking a bit about web standards today what they are uh how they are made and how we are moving them forward
faster today than we have in the past so uh my name is bear Travis uh you can find me on GitHub atbe Travis which is
where these slides we posted after the talk or on Twitter at bearor Travis where you can pay me with any questions
you might have so a bit about me um I work at the web engine team at Adobe and besides
having a penchant for blue beanies we occasionally do work on web standards both uh creating them and implementing
them in engines like webkit so I've already set it a couple
times already so you may be wondering you know what is a web standard what qualifies and what doesn't um and so I
found this definition that I like um called by Roger Johansson who said web standards are Technologies established
by the w3c and other standards bodies that are used to create and interpret web-based content these Technologies are
designed to future future proof documents published on the web and to make those documents accessible to as
many people and devices as possible and I like this definition of web standards because they kind of describe what web
standards aspire to be like when you have standards you can create documents that are future proof they will work
today as well as they will 5 years from now um you're also making web making
documents accessible to as many people um accessing your content as possible
you know they may come at your content from a whole bunch of different angles and standards help ensure that people will reliably see that content so one of
the things that's unique about the web um is that the web is viewed by uh a lot of different
people on different devices from desktop to tablets to mobile um using all sorts
of different browsers and unlike many other development environments um when you're working on the web you don't
necessarily control how your content is going to be viewed um your users could be using any of these browsers any of
these devices you know in any area across the globe accessing your content and expecting it to work when you're
developing for something um like iOS or Android you may have more reasonable expectations about what platform um your
end user is going to be using because that's all your content is going to be accessible um but with the web uh people
can access it pretty much anywhere um so
uh what does that boil down to from an end users's perspective uh what it means is that you should be able to write uh
markup once and have a reasonable expectation for what it should display so like you
should only have to describe this once um to a browser and have it reasonably display the same content all across
browsers and across devices and so what what this comes down
to is basically do browsers reliably Implement a feature can you use uh one
one feature and expect all of the browsers to reliably show the same thing and so I figure that it would be
fun to kind of wake people up in the afternoon and take a poll um so media queries are one of the the kind of
relatively new features that enable you to customize the CSS for different devices um and kind of different form
factors um that people may be using so how many of you feel relatively comfortable using media queries and
browsers today cool I mean it feels like they've been around for forever right um so in
terms of browser support um they're supported pretty much across the board um you just have to be aware that they
were kind of implemented in I9 plus um so be careful browsers less than that
how about gradients uh have any of you guys used gradients in your websites yep I love them too I kind of
abuse them and make really ugly ones um but I'm sure that some of you have used them quite Tastefully um so gradients
are relatively new um there's browser supports only relatively Fair um they
are implemented in IE 10 plus uh and they are still prefixed in Safari and chrome and they're not yet in oper
mobile so border radius this one does feel like it's been around for forever how many of you guys have used border
radius in your websites yeah so pretty much everyone um I use it a ton too um
and it turns out that uh again this is on I9 plus uh and not yet on oper
mobile so you may be asking you know what happens when you don't have standards things may be implemented in
one browser and you know we really just want to see if we can use it um you don't have standards you may wind up
having to kind of write duplicate code to accomplish the same effect so this is an example of adding an event listener
just for a simple click event um and on the top you kind of have what eventually became the standard ad event listener um
and Below you have kind of what was one of the early syntaxes on Internet Explorer and so here you see that you're
doing the same thing but you're having to write uh two code paths for it not
fun um and you may be asking you know well all of the kind of more modern
browsers are using this but if you look at kind of conservative estimates it places IE uh versions like uh below n
it's still like 9% of the people who may be viewing your content and this is like on on the very very low side of those
estimates um so if you really want to Target all of your users you're going to have to
write both of these code paths okay and then there's also kind of
the case that happens when standards evolve after some functionality has already gotten out in the wild um so
this happened with uh gradients which we talked a bit about
earlier so there was no real standard for grade gradients um but people obviously wanted them and so Microsoft
started experimenting with uh early syntaxes in uh Internet Explorer versions as low as six um but as you can
tell like it's not really standardized they're kind of still ideating let's say um it's a
little bit long and a little bit ugly um and it's not even uh valid CSS so later
on in version 8 they added kind of the MS prefix and they made it kind of a valid CSS property but no other browsers
were really implementing it yet and then Apple came along with its own proposal um and decided to do an
implementation in webkit so this made it into uh Safari and chrome and they kind
of introduced this webkit gradient syntax but this never really made it to any of the standards bodies either um
and so it wasn't until Milla came around and said you know maybe we should work towards making a standard that all of
the browsers can imple Implement and they came up with uh this syntax and so you know this syntax is
kind of currently supported by most of the major browser vendors the current ones and it's getting to become kind of
a standard and something that you can use and reliably expect um but you can see that it's really only The Cutting
Edge browsers so when you're talking about Internet Explorer 10 plus you know you're still missing about 177% of the
market which means that in order to get this to reliably run you may have to write all of those other um syntaxes in
one definition so you may get like 10 lines of filter definitions just in order to get this to reliably run on as
many browsers as possible uh so when standards take too
long to develop you start getting things like uh quirks mode basically when documents in the Wild start relying on
non-standard behavior and you have to kind of keep that around in browsers and nobody really likes that um and you
start talking about Legacy browsers basically um when you have to start talking about browsers that have behaviors that you don't
want so in terms of kind of getting all the players together and making them uh
kind of conform to standards standards bodies are really the people who who do that work um and one of the major ones
is the w3c um which is one of the main drivers for CSS um so the w3c has a more
technical definition of what a standard is because they want to be able to Define concretely what matches that
definition and what doesn't so they say the w3c publishes documents that Define web Technologies these documents follow
a process designed to promote consensus fairness public accountability and quality at the end of this process the
w3c publishes recommendations which are considered web standards so you can see that from the w3c's perspective it's
more about specifying or writing down standards than getting the actual Behavior out in the browsers like what
they want to do is they want to go through a formal process writing this document up coming up with a specification which goes on to become a
recommendation and that they say is a web standard so the w3c process um is very
defined as they mentioned before um there are three major stages they have a working draft stage where uh
specifications are basically being uh they're basically subject to public review uh and they can be kind of
seriously revised during this stage they then go on to become a submission um to become a candidate recommendation and
from there the specification has to have two working implementations and a test Suite
that says whether or not browsers have effectively implemented that specification from there the candidate
recommendation can go on to become a proposed recommendation and become accepted by the w3c as a recommendation
what they consider a web standard so who exactly takes part in
the w3c process one of the nice things about uh the w3c process is that a lot of people are involved um so there are
obviously the specification authors the people writing these specifications they're the specification implementers
the people who are actually implementing it in the browsers and there is the community
basically anyone can comment on these specifications and help move move them forward and so as an example of how that
has worked in the past I wanted to talk about CSS grid layout um and what CSS grid layout is at its most fundamental
is you can kind of think of it as as super tables um they're kind of a way of making tables that flexibly resized to
fit their containers and so what you can do is you can kind of define flexible rows and columns and then assign
elements um to those cells but um this is largely still taking elements and assigning them to cells within your grid
and when front-end developers and web designers start thinking about grids they actually think about something more like this so this is the golden grid
system but you can see similar ones in like uh bootstrapper zerb uh zerbs
Foundation where what you have is you have kind of a set of measurements and then you start aligning and sizing items
to those measurements what you're more interested in is kind of aligning to the grid lines rather than aligning to the cells created by those grid lines this
helps you kind of create responsive uh layouts where elements can resize and you can dynamically change the grid
and so some people from the community as they were starting to review this CSS grid spec said you know hey what you're
writing is great but in order for this to be really useful for me I need to be able to align and size items to the grid
lines not just to the grid cells and so uh CSS grid layout
introduced line based placement where basically you could Define um the start and end points or define basically the
widths of elements based on lines in the grid
and so in terms of talking about specifications from a recommendation point of view um we can kind of revisit
those three specs that those three features that I talked about earlier uh and see where they are in the w3c
specification process so media queries how many of you
guys think that this meets the w3c definition of a web standard as a w3c
recommendation so we got one person with their fingers cross um so this did go on
to become a recommendation um but it was only last summer uh that that became a formal recommendation even though it
feels like media aquaries have been around for a much longer
time how about gradients how many of you guys think that we've reached the recommendation standpoint for
gradients okay I'm seeing some some kind of shakes of the head and you would be right so uh gradients are part of the
CSS image values and replaced content specification this is currently in that Canada recommendation St candidate
recommendation stage where basically they're trying out implementations they've more or less finalized what they think should work but they want to make
sure that it can actually be implemented in browsers um so this is a candidate recommendation it went on to become that
in last spring and finally border radius um so
this has been around for a while lots of people are using it today how many of you guys think that this meets the definition of a w3c recommendation I see
a couple hands um so this is part of a larger specification called CSS backgrounds and borders um and this is
actually surprisingly still in the candidate recommendation stage um so this kind of shows how specifications
and kind of the w3c recommendations may actually lag behind what people are actually using in browsers today and
what many of us consider to be web standards so then I guess the question
becomes which definition uh do we use for web standards do we use what is available in
the web browsers basically what we're comfortable using and how display reliably uh across whatever browser or
user may be using or is it what kind of we have defined and have uh written
specification for that's gone through this review process and what that kind of influences
is where do we focus if we want to move web standards forward as fast as possible do we focus more on the implementation side or more on kind of
writing um and codifying the
behavior and so to give kind of an answer to this question I'd like to go over a little bit of History um because
you know hindsight is much easier than say future predictions um and talk about uh the past for
CSS so in 1990 Tim burner Lee develops the first uh web page and web browser um
in 1994 the w3c is formed to help shape web
standards in 1995 we get the first public working draft of
css1 this moves very quickly and in 1996 becomes a recommendation so you can see that
there's basically a one-year turnaround from actually writing that to getting it as a w3c recommendation 1997 we get the
first public draft of css2 and in 1998 that goes on to become a
recommendation in 2000 the w3c starts thinking about css3 um but then in 2002 they go back
and kind of revisit some of the Arata in CSS 2 on start working on revision one
and then that takes 10 years um to become a recommendation and so one of the
questions may be why does css2 revision one take 10 years of work whereas CSS
one and css2 had really only taken one year um to get a recommendation um and the reason was that css2 lacked a
candidate recommendation stage before it went on to become a recommendation so if you remember that candidate
recommendation stage is basically where uh a specification is put on hold until it's proven that two browsers are
actually interested and can implement it um so what happened was a lot of browsers actually diverged from the
recommendation for css2 that the the w3c put out um and so uh some material was
just slightly different and so CSS 2.1 um just was slightly altered in the behavior from css2 um some browsers
expressed basically no interest in implementing parts of css2 and so those sections were removed in CSS 2.1 um and
then some some material was added where browsers had basically gone off and innovated and created new behaviors and
more or less standardized on them um before the WCC had gone around to writing specifications for
them and so what this kind of shows is that standards synthesize implementation and uh specification it's not really
about one or the other it's about both um you need to move forward both forward
at the same time in order to effectively create web standards um if you have specifications that outpace
implementation um you have things like CSS 2.1 where the final implementations May significantly diverge from what's
written in the specification if you have implementation that outpaces specification you may wind
up with things like filters where basically the browsers have gone off and done kind of crazy things on their own um and in order to kind of Corral them
back in you wind up with all these kind of leg Legacy syntaxes that you have to fix up and support until you can
reliably expect all of your users to be using standards compliant
browsers and so the w3c is kind of a driving force behind this it makes for it makes sure that specifications move
forward um and also that kind of browser vendors are on board with implementing these
standards and then just the final thing is that standards are continuously evolving as you can see from uh the
example of css2 it wasn't like the specification was done and that was a standard um really the browsers had
continued to implement new functionality and what they implemented and what kind of CSS 2.1 came to agree on really
became standards on the
web so uh where do these ideas from for web standards come from um obviously
there's there are some standards that basically just codify existing behaviors in web browsers but sometimes the w3c is
thinking more about what is coming down the line like what is kind of what people are interested in using in the
future future um so they kind of have to do some brainstorming about where the web will be several years from
now and so an example of this is just text layout on the web like there are a lot of different features um being
actively developed today um including some by Adobe helping people do more
complicated layouts on the web and kind of as a history of text layout just the simplest version is you
know the scroll it's been around for a while you lay out text from left to right from top to bottom um and you need
as much space as you have text so the scroll basically becomes as long as you need it to fit all of your
content as your layout gets more complex you may begin kind of playing with that layout so that uh you can wrap text
through say multiple columns you can wrap it in non-rectangular areas so in
this case we are avoiding this fish shaped area in the center um and wrapping text around it
and then eventually as as our uh content gets really long we may start actually dividing it into things like Pages um so
that we don't have to have just one long Scroll of content um and so we can kind of divide it into pages and then bind it
in something like a book and we can see that these layouts are still very much in play today so in
something like a magazine layout you may have kind of multiple articles running through custom areas avoiding figures um
like these bottles here and then of course this is all going to be bound into a magazine which is
paginated and on the web like layout has started off uh very simply and is starting today to kind of explore some
of these more complex layouts so at its simplest and occasionally it's most elegant um you
still have the scrolling area of content you have basically a web page it lays
out text from left to right from top to bottom the web page is as long as it needs to be in order to fit that that
content and the user will just scroll down in order to view all of
it but uh like this site here which is from TVs safety.org um people are
starting to play with different ways of laying out the content so here we are laying out text within uh these circular
bubbles here um and text is kind of wrapping to fit inside of them and then we've also got these arrows on the left
and right in order to navigate this and using this we're going to navigate through multiple pages of cont content
rather than just scrolling through them and so you can see that they've kind of divided their experience uh into
pages and then there are kind of some online magazine layouts that are becoming popular today too um this is
from the great discontent and what you can see is basically they have one stream of content flowing down the center um above and below this diagram
and then what they've done is they've inserted a picture and a quote um here into this stream of content so they basically have magazine content that is
broken up on being surrounded by figures and
quotes uh but these more complicate these more complicated layouts are still a little bit tricky uh to accomplish on
the web and one of the largest reasons is because in order to express something on the web as I mentioned earlier you
have to be able to describe it uh in the vocabulary that browsers will understand
you have to describe it in markup you know HTML CSS JavaScript um and what happens when you have something like
this so you have content that wraps more tightly around this capital A here um
and what happens when you have something like this also running through multiple columns where you don't have an easy
translation to vocabulary uh that the browsers will understand an easy translation to markup so what do you write then and I mean you can get these
Effects by writing kind of complicated things you can start dividing all of your text into spans and do complicated floats um but it's hard it's not
straightforward and so regions and exclusions are two of
the standards that adobe is currently working on in order to make these layouts easier in order to make it easier to basically customize how
content flows through documents on the
web regions um basically customize the containers that you can flow text
through so rather than just flowing content through its current box you can specify areas and then flow content
through them so here we have a stream of content the gray content that we're going to flow through boxes one 2 3 and
four and then we also have this white stream of content down here that we're going to flow through boxes A and B and these boxes that we're flowing content
through are called regions and the content that we're flowing through them is called a flow and so the markup for it looks like
this um basically you specify that your content is going to go into the flow basically something that regions can
pull from later and then you're going to mark all of your regions with this region class and you will pull content
from it using the flow from
property exclusions are basically a complement to Regions and what they allow you to do is they allow you to
customize uh the shapes that content flows inside and around so here we can see that content is Flowing inside of
this circular shape and also content outside of it is respecting the same circular
contour and the market for this is again pretty simple what we have is we have this circular shape it's floating on the
left so you can see that this is that Circle there and what we do is we customize the
shape outside which is the shape the content outside of it is going to respect on the float um we specify that as a circle centered at 50% 50% um with
a radius of 50% um and then we specify that the shape inside is going to respect the same shape as the shape
outside is also going to be wrapped inside of that circular
shape so I have two quick demos uh of this functionality just so you can you can see it in
action okay I'm not going to try and full screen it
uh so this um is basically just an example of flowing content through two
columns and again wrapping it around that drop cap um and we can see that all of these columns are kind of sized to be
about the size of the viewport um so people can basically scroll down the content and see this multiple column
experience and all of this content is Again part of basically just one div that's marked as content and then flowed
through these multiple
regions and then this is an example of just customizing the shape inside um so we can do kind of something a little bit
eccentric like flowing text through this tail shape on the mouse and you can see that you know if we say zoom in um then
it's not something like an image it's going to actually be the text so it appears nice and crisp and
clean okay so Adobe is trying to kind of move these and get these into the hands of web developers as quickly as possible
and how do we accomplish this today um so of course because we're working
both in specifications and implementations it's important to move both of them faster um so we'll talk about the specification
piece first and one of the simplest ways to move specifications forward faster is by
reducing their complexity um so CSS one just as a measure of complexity started out with
about 25,000 words CSS 2 had about
92,000 CSS 2.1 had about 140,000 and then CSS 3 which is still
very much in flux so standards are kind of being being added or removed from it um this was a count I did back a couple of months ago it's currently at about
390,000 words you can see that like it's getting much more complex and trying to
finalize something all in one go um is going to take a lot longer um and so
what uh specifications and standards do these days is they basically move
forward individually um they're broken up into modules and then each of those modules can move forward with testing
and specification and implementation all separately so one specification actually finalize um in the level three spec and
move on to level four before another spec may actually finalize its level three um and so as an example of
basically how much the w3c is doing this especially with CSS um is this is the list of current CSS works that the w3c
is doing um and there are about 50 plus specs that have currently been broken apart and are currently moving forward
individually there so regions and exclusions are kind
of examples of this new modular philosophy they were actually proposed initially as a single spec uh and then
the w3c you know kind of said you know there may be enough here to actually make it two um and so they were broken
up um into two separate specifications um and kind of ideas that
have come along since have either reused functionality defined in regions and exclusions or um kind of been spun off
into new specifications so that these two can remain as focused and lightweight as possible so for example when you're
using regions basically flowing content through custom areas um it may be nice to Define templates um so you basically
reuse that template as many times as you need in order to uh place all of your
content into these templates um and this was an idea like hey it's really useful to define a
template with regions so you can basically flow your content reuse the template um as many times as you need um
in order to kind of make a nice paginated view um but rather than include this in the region spec it was
spun off into a different spe specification um called the the page template specification conveniently
enough um that can be moved forward independently another example of this is
fragmentation um the idea that basically you want to be able to specify brakes across region in your content and
originally this had been part of the region specification uh because well it
was important to be there um but it turns out that there are several other uh features that are currently being
worked on that break content across multiple containers ERS um and a lot of that behavior is being codified in
something called the CSS fragmentation specification um and they also specify how content breaks across these multiple
fragments and so rather than kind of having a separate definition in the region region specification um the
breaking Behavior was moved over into the CSS fragmentation
spec and then uh there was CSS masking uh which folks have kind of started to codify how content can be clipped and
masked in CSS um and one of the asks for this feature was being able to specify
shapes um that you can clip content with in CSS so you need to be able to Define
shapes to clip content um using CSS markup and because CSS exclusions and shapes already has a Syntax for that on
the CSS masking spec just reuses that
syntax but it turns out there's kind of a limit um to how modular or lightweight we can make any individual module and
one of the reasons for this is that each module is really part of a larger tool set in order for these modules to be
successful as features you really need to be able to use them effectively with any other feature in the tool set that
you may want to so as an example of this C CSS regions and exclusions were proposed as
a single specification because they're supposed to play well together so you should be able to um Define custom
regions in your content you should be able to customize the shapes of those regions and how content flows through them um so in this example you can see
that you kind of have CSS regions and exclusions as one stream of text running through two regions um with these
triangle shapes applied to them and so you know in the markup this is pretty simple you have regions they
have a shape inside which customizes the shape that the content flows inside and then you have content which is going to
be flowed through them but then the question comes up well
what happens if both the regions and the content have a shape inside on them so in this example what happens if you have
these triangle shapes on the two regions on the left and right and then the content itself that you're flowing
through it has say a circular shape and so what we've decided to do
for right now is basically uh use the intersection of those two shapes but it's kind of an example of how you need
to think about how specifications interact U when you're writing them and implementing
them another example of this uh is regions in multicolumn so you can use uh regions basically to break break up uh
multicolumn elements so in here you could say have multiple pages that you
use regions for and inside each of those pages you have a multicolumn layout so it's something like we saw in the Alice
demo where we want content to flow uh through these columns first and then move on to the next page and flow
through the columns there but if we're not careful in
specifying kind of which of these containers has priority content might flow through the columns first and then
be broken up into separate pages rather than flowing through the regions first and breaking up into columns and so you might wind up with basically these super
long columns that are broken up across pages and this obviously isn't what you want either so you need to make sure
that your specifications work well together and so the flip side of writing
faster specifications is getting faster implementations basically getting this functionality available to people
faster um and one of the things we're seeing today is that web browsers are uh releasing just much faster than they
have in the past so uh all of the major browsers are releasing test builds before their final release versions go
out so if you're interested in trying out features I would encourage you to download and try out their test builds
um many browsers are also releasing something called an experimental Channel something like uh Chrome Canary or
Aurora for Firefox um which basically installs alongside your standard release
browser automatically updates um to the latest build and so basically you have a browser where you can test out
experimental features without having to download a new version all the time um and it also kind of doesn't overwrite uh
your current browser so you can go back to your regular release browser when you want your everyday browsing experience
other part of this is that release builds um are also coming out more frequently than in the past so your
actual like the browser that you use every day is coming out more frequently than in the past because in the past
we've had release Cycles say you know every year every two years um and obviously the web is moving forward a
bit faster than that so we're seeing release Cycles in as short as six weeks with some of the major browsers
today so native implementations have a couple benefits um they prove that a feature can be done they prove that it
can be done in a performant manner uh and they prove that it can be done just like any other web feature after all you
know it is a web feature when it's made it into browsers um the downsides of native implementations though are that
uh you're tied to a specific browser when you implement it um your code isn't
going to go out except for on the release for that browser um and because it's a shipping product it may have
really kind of high standards for review and implementation um so getting code out in
a browser release can take a bit of time and it's only going to be in only one
browser
so so what we really want to do is we want to get functionality uh in the hands of people faster um because what
it boils down to is letting people play with these features see if they do what they need them to and then getting
feedback on the specification um so one of the ways we're doing this today is
using polyfills so how many of you guys have used a polyfill in web development how many of you have you
heard polyfills is a big buzzword okay so I'll go over them really fast um the basic idea is that
you uh have something like a JavaScript library it sits on top of your uh HTML uh and
when you have a new feature that's implemented in some browsers but not all especially something like Legacy
browsers the polyfill will go through your document and transform it into something that older browsers can understand the idea being here that you
can use newer features that are supported on some of the newer browsers and then you'll have a fallback uh for older
browsers but what we're seeing today uh is that people are starting to play around with polyfills before reliable
implementations have actually been released on any browser um and so what you're seeing is that people are starting to release polyfills so you can
play around um with basically the newest Cutting Edge features that are currently
being worked on in the w3c uh so the advantages of polyfills of
course are that they work now uh they can work across browsers uh if people take the time to do that uh they can be
replaced by native functionality because you know again this functionality is supposed to be supported in the future
we're only kind of backfilling it um with some JavaScript and some ex additional markup for now um and they
also kind of let you try out new
features so example of this is uh the codepen rodeo uh and what happened was
codepen was doing a series of basically kind of uh user experiments
basically it would uh give a topic for a week let people try around try to play
around um with that challenge and kind of see what people created and what they came up with um and because Adobe had
released a polyfill uh for Regions we were actually able to do a uh regions uh
challenge one week and so the great thing about having a polyfill was basically people could use it with their browser of choice uh they could go
through and kind of start playing around with it without kind of downloading a fancy uh test browser or anything um and
they could start just kind of seeing what they could build um and so it was really great to to see what people tried
to create um with regions and what they were kind of interested in doing and this is again when we don't have a
reliable implementation uh available by default in any
browser so of course there are a couple downsides to polyfills uh they are a workaround of oh they are work around of
course um because the feature isn't implemented yet um polyfills start
getting written relatively early in the specification process a lot of the time uh and so you can see the specification
change and sometimes there significant changes uh in the specification and that means that all of the code that you took
so long to get working uh with the polyfill for the native implementation to work later May wind up being out of
date and then the other uh final reason is or downside of polyils is that they
can be a bit non-performance they're doing a lot of work on the client side uh sometimes in order to get markup that
simulates this effect that you're going for on older browsers um and so they can
they can be a bit slow
so if you are interested um I have up here A bunch of
kind of polyfills that I think are really cool that you can play around um up on the modernizer site which I've
linked at the bottom uh there are a bunch more basically for any specification that's out there uh on the
web that you might be interested in using there's probably a polyfill for it um and so I would encourage you to go
and check them out
so the cool thing about standards today is that they aren't standing still uh the implementation and specification pieces are moving forward all the time
we're getting new polyfills out there um and so kind of what you might actually be able to use uh can change uh on a
daily basis as people release new functionality with browsers
um this is an older version of The Talk um so standards are basically
uh they're tools um and uh the goal for them is basically for
you to be able to write you want to get something on the web and you should be able to describe
